results.title: The Land of Senegal
results.creator_credit: Guy Sarthoulet, Office de Radiodiffusion Television Francais and United Nations Television
results.brief_description: Dakar, the capital city of the West African country of Senegal, is a magnet for thousands of farmers who flock into town and then cannot find work. The country has a one-crop economy - but peanuts are particularly vulnerable to market price fluctuations, so the Government of Senegal has asked for United Nations help in diversifying agriculture and training a new class of craftsmen and skilled cultivators.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Guy Sarthoulet, Office de Radiodiffusion Television Francais and United Nations Television

results.title: The Land of Robert Burns
results.creator_credit: Joe Mendoza, Stewart McAllister and British Transport Films
results.brief_description: This short account of the poet’s life is set among contemporary scenes of the people of south-west Scotland as they grow from childhood to adulthood. A representative selection of his songs, sung by the Saltire singers, takes on fresh significance when heard against a background of the people and the countryside he knew and loved.

results.title: The Land of lots of time
results.brief_description: A fascinating trip from the Murray Gulf to the S.W. of N.S.W. with Graham Pizzey, well known naturalist. The emphasis is on how wildlife adapts to habitat.

results.title: The Land must provide
results.creator_credit: Philip Owtram, Douglas Gordon and Shell Film Unit
results.brief_description: The major increases in food productin required to feed a rapidly increasing world population must come from raising crop yields on existing cultivated land, although much of the world’s land has become exhausted by endless use. This land can be made fertile again provided that there is sufficient moisture and by the introduction of the right balance of nutrients, such as that provided by chemical fertilisers.

results.title: The Land is me
results.brief_description: In addition to writing and singing the theme song, 10 year old Shannon scripted, animated and helped edit this short film about the impact of early Australian settlement on Aboriginal cultures. Overall Winner of the Screen It! competition 2004. An animated short entered to “Create a moving image work on the theme ‘Pacific Explorer” section of ACMI’s ‘Screen It’ media making competition for Primary Schools.

results.title: The Land
results.creator_credit: Robert Joseph Flaherty, Department of Agriculture and National Audio Visual Center
results.brief_description: Robert Flaherty’s images create an impressive study of the problems of American agriculture during the depression and the eventual ruin of vast tracts of land in the midwest. Looks at problems such as erosion, overproduction, mechanisation and the influx of migrant workers. Commentary: Russell Lord

results.title: The Lake district
results.creator_credit: Alex Strasser, Edgar H. Anstey and British Transport Films
results.brief_description: The English Lake District, an unspoiled region of mountains and lakes in the north-west of England. Now a national park where climbing, walking, sailing, and fishing may be enjoyed, and pilgrims may pay homage to Wordsworth and the district which inspired him. Narrated by Michael Redgrave.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Alex Strasser, Edgar H. Anstey and British Transport Films

results.title: The Ladybird story
results.creator_credit: Pat Dowling and Pat Dowling Pictures
results.brief_description: The discovery of the Vedalia ladybird beetle in Australia, in 1885; how it benefits humans in controlling harmful pests; exported to America where an entire industry was threatened by the cottony-cushion scale. Life cycle of scale and beetle shown in closeup.

results.title: The Kremlin
results.brief_description: A guided tour of the Kremlin recreating events in Russian history associated with the building from the 12th century up until its present day role as a museum and seat of the Social Government. Shows the great halls, paintings, ikons and treasures which belonged to the Czars.

results.title: The Koorie Oral History Program and the Bill Onus family archive
results.brief_description: Koorie people record ourselves as a means of self-representation, to destroy stereotypes and to ensure that we are not erased. These films from the Koori Oral History Program and the Bill Onus family archive preserve our culture and kinship for future generations.

constellations_primary.name: Connecting through film
constellations_primary.description: Film acts like a time capsule to our collective past. Capturing our most treasured moments with family has never been more accessible, with technology right at our fingers.

results.title_for_label: The Koorie Oral History Program and the Bill Onus family archive
results.description:
Koorie people record ourselves as a means of self-representation, to destroy stereotypes and to ensure that we are not erased. These films from the Koorie Oral History Program and the Bill Onus family archive preserve our culture and kinship for future generations.

“When we talk about Traditional Aboriginal knowledge in Victoria we need to remember it is one of the oldest living forms of communication in the world. It continues today as one of the main mediums through which cultural knowledge and story lines are passed on. The images you will see in this exhibition reflect the value and importance of oral knowledge as an ongoing and vibrant cultural link with the past.” - Dr Wayne Atkinson senior Yorta Yorta Elder and creator of the Koorie Oral History Program
description_for_label:
Koorie people record ourselves as a means of self-representation, to destroy stereotypes and to ensure that we are not erased. These films from the Koorie Oral History Program and the Bill Onus family archive preserve our culture and kinship for future generations.

“When we talk about Traditional Aboriginal knowledge in Victoria we need to remember it is one of the oldest living forms of communication in the world. It continues today as one of the main mediums through which cultural knowledge and story lines are passed on. The images you will see in this exhibition reflect the value and importance of oral knowledge as an ongoing and vibrant cultural link with the past.” - Dr Wayne Atkinson senior Yorta Yorta Elder and creator of the Koorie Oral History Program
